Option D. HSV show periodic lateralized epileptiform discharge (PLED) arising from temporal lobes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease is associated with distinct EEG findings that are crucial for its diagnosis. Understanding the typical EEG patterns along with clinical presentation and advanced imaging can aid in the early and accurate diagnosis of this rapidly progressive and fatal disease.

 

Reference - Harrison 21e/Neurology/Dementia/chap 438/12420

questions.text: What is the most common complication of the central line insertion below the marked bone? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Arterial puncture

 

Explanation:

 

The bone indicated in the image above is the left clavicle. An arterial puncture is the most common complication of a central line insertion below this bone.

 

  • Complications of central vein catheterization are - 
    • Arterial puncture- this is the most common complication.
    • Cardiac tamponade is the most important life-threatening complication. It occurs as a result of puncture of intrapericardial superior vena cava, right atrium, or right ventricle.
    • Pneumothorax- injury to the underlying pleura may lead to pneumothorax. This is more common in subclavian vein catheterization.
    • Chylothorax can occur particularly in left subclavian vein catheterization. But it is not the most common.
    • Injury to the associated nerves like brachial plexus, stellate ganglion, phrenic nerve, or vocal cords.
    • Thromboembolism leading to venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism is more common with femoral veins.
    • Infections

 

 Other Options:

 

Option B. Thrombophlebitis: Thrombophlebitis refers to inflammation of a vein associated with clot formation. While thrombophlebitis can occur following any central line placement, it's more commonly associated with peripheral IV lines. However, central venous catheters are more commonly associated with deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which is the formation of a blood clot inside the larger, deeper veins.

 

Option C. Empyema: Empyema refers to the accumulation of pus in the pleural cavity. While empyema itself is not a direct complication of central line placement, pneumothorax or hemothorax (air or blood in the pleural space, respectively) caused by central line placement can lead to infection and subsequently empyema if not recognized and treated.

 

Option D. Chylothorax: Chylothorax is the accumulation of lymphatic fluid in the pleural space. This can happen if the thoracic duct is damaged. The thoracic duct is a major lymphatic vessel that runs in the thorax but is not typically at risk with subclavian line placement. Chylothorax would be more of a concern with procedures that are done in close proximity to the thoracic duct, like surgeries or interventions in the mediastinum or around the esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arterial puncture is one of the most common complications associated with the subclavian approach for central venous catheter placement. The subclavian artery lies directly beneath the vein, so inadvertent puncture of the artery can occur if the needle is advanced too deeply or at an incorrect angle. Accidental puncture of the subclavian artery can lead to complications such as hematoma, hemothorax, and can also be problematic if not recognized because threading a catheter into the arterial system can have catastrophic consequences.

choices.text: 2, 4, and 5
1, 2, and 3
1, 3, and 4

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is correct regarding Peutz-Jeghers syndrome? (AIIMS NOV 2020)

 

  1. Arborizing pattern of smooth muscle
  2. Loss of heterozygosity in the STK11 gene
  3. Multiple Gl polyps
  4. Autosomal recessive
  5. Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium is seen
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, and 3

 

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant, hereditary disorder.

 

Characterized by

 

  • Multiple intestinal hamartomatous polyps having an arborizing pattern of smooth muscle.
  • Mucocutaneous dark blue to brown melanin pigmentation, which is particularly evident on the face, buccal mucosa, hands, feet, perianal and genital regions

 

 

Germline heterozygous loss-of-function mutations in the STK11 gene are present in approximately half of individuals with familial Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

 

Presents at a median age of 11 years.

 

The hamartomatous polyps seen in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome are characterized by a branching network of smooth muscle fibers continuous with the muscularis mucosa that supports the glandular epithelium of the polyp.

 

 

Complications:

 

  • Intussusception, which is occasionally fatal.
  • Markedly increased risk of many malignant conditions. Lifetime risk is approximately 40% and regular surveillance is recommended from a very young age for sex cord tumors of the testes.
  • During later life, there is a risk for gastric and small intestinal cancers, and subsequently for colon, pancreatic (100%), breast, lung, ovarian, and uterine cancers.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Autosomal recessive (4): Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is not autosomal recessive; it is autosomal dominant.
  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (5): This is a feature associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), not Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is characterized by an arborizing pattern of smooth muscle, loss of heterozygosity in the STK11 gene, and multiple GI polyps, and it is autosomal dominant.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1557

choices.text: Inferior vena cava
Right atrium
Superior vena cava

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inferior vena cava

 

Explanation

 

  • Inferior vena cava has the highest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation.
  • Fetal heart pumps large quantity of blood into the placenta for exchange of substances.
  • From placenta, the umbilical veins collect the blood, which has more oxygen and nutrients.
  • Umbilical vein passes through liver, some amount of blood is supplied to liver from umbilical vein, large quantity of blood is diverted from umbilical vein into the inferior vena cava through ductus venosus.
  • Liver receives blood from portal vein also.
  • In liver, the oxygenated blood mixes slightly with deoxygenated blood and enters the right atrium via inferior vena cava.
  • From right atrium, major portion of blood is diverted into left atrium via foramen ovale. Foramen ovale is an opening in intra-atrial septum.
  • Blood from upper part of the body enters the right atrium through superior vena cava. From right atrium, blood enters right ventricle.
  • Then, blood is pumped into pulmonary artery. From pulmonary artery, blood enters the systemic aorta through ductus arteriosus.
  • Only a small quantity of blood is supplied to fetal lungs. Blood from left ventricle is pumped into aorta.
  • Fifty percent of blood from aorta reaches the placenta through umbilical arteries.

 

 

Mixing potentially occurs at 4 sites:

 

  1. Left umbilical vein (Oxygen saturation ~80%) – Portal vein (Much bypassed by ductus venosus to Inferior Vena cava)
  2. Left umbilical vein – Inferior vena cava – Portal vein (Oxygen saturation of IVC blood is ~65%)
  3. Superior vena cava – Right atrium (Much bypassed by Foramen ovale)
  4. Pulmonary veins – Left atrium (Much bypassed by Foramen ovale and ductus arteriosus)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right atrium: Incorrect. While the right atrium receives blood from the inferior vena cava, it also receives deoxygenated blood from the superior vena cava, leading to a mixture that has a lower oxygen concentration than the incoming blood from the inferior vena cava.

 

Option C. Superior vena cava: Incorrect. The superior vena cava carries deoxygenated blood from the head and upper limbs of the fetus, thus having a lower oxygen concentration.

 

Option D. Ascending aorta: Incorrect. Although the ascending aorta in the fetus does carry oxygenated blood, the highest concentration of oxygen is found in the blood before it reaches the heart, specifically in the inferior vena cava due to the direct input from the umbilical vein through the ductus venosus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The highest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation is found in the inferior vena cava due to its receipt of oxygen-rich blood from the umbilical vein, which has directly exchanged gases in the placenta. This setup is crucial for delivering a sufficient oxygen supply to the developing fetus.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs causes activation of K+ channels? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nicorandil

 

Nicorandil is a drug that causes the activation of K+ channels. It is unique among the options listed because it acts as both a potassium channel opener and has nitrate-like effects, which contribute to its vasodilatory properties. By opening potassium channels, nicorandil causes hyperpolarization of the vascular smooth muscle cells, leading to relaxation and vasodilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Molsidomine: Molsidomine is a nitric oxide donor that works by activating guanylate cyclase, increasing cyclic GMP (cGMP) levels, and causing vasodilation. It does not activate K+ channels.

 

Option C. Isosorbide dinitrate: Isosorbide dinitrate is also a nitric oxide donor that acts by increasing cGMP levels through the activation of guanylate cyclase, leading to vasodilation.

 

Option D. Nitroglycerin: Nitroglycerin is another nitric oxide donor that causes vasodilation by increasing cGMP levels through the activation of guanylate cyclase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nicorandil is the drug that causes activation of K+ channels, leading to hyperpolarization and vasodilation. It also has nitrate-like effects, distinguishing it from other nitric oxide donors like molsidomine, isosorbide dinitrate, and nitroglycerin, which do not activate K+ channels but work by increasing cGMP levels.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a fall from height. The patient reports no pain or injury, but on examination, there is blood at the tip of the urethral meatus. The patient is hemodynamically stable with no other injuries. The next step in management would be? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ascending urethrogram

 

  • The clinical scenario suggests a suspected urethral injury with blood at the urethral meatus, which is commonly caused by external trauma or instrumentation.
  •  To confirm urethral rupture, the next step would be an ascending urethrogram.
  • Ascending urethrogram: Correct. In a patient who is hemodynamically stable and without symptoms of a full bladder, retrograde urethrography will help determine the extent of the injury and decide on the next appropriate steps.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foley's catheterization: In the setting of suspected urethral injury, as evidenced by the presence of blood at the tip of the urethral meatus, inserting a Foley catheter can be harmful. It could potentially exacerbate the injury or convert a partial tear into a complete one. Hence, this is contraindicated without first confirming the integrity of the urethra.

 

Option C. Nephrogram: A nephrogram is an imaging study of the kidneys and their function. While it can give details about the upper urinary tract, it's not typically used for evaluating urethral injuries.

 

Option D. Suprapubic cystostomy: Suprapubic cystostomy, or suprapubic catheter placement, involves inserting a catheter directly into the bladder through the abdominal wall. It's done to divert urine when urethral catheterization is not possible or contraindicated, such as in the setting of a known or suspected urethral injury. This will be attempted after an urethrogram confirms a rupture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To confirm urethral rupture in a patient with suspected urethral injury, an ascending urethrogram is the next step in management.
  • Foley's catheterization should be avoided as it may exacerbate the injury.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of recurrent skin infections is admitted to the hospital for cellulitis. He has been treated with penicillin in the past but his current infection is not responding well to the treatment. The healthcare team suspects that the infecting bacteria may produce beta-lactamases and are considering alternative antibiotics. What is the mechanism of resistance by beta-lactamases to penicillins? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Degradation of antibiotics.

 

Beta-lactamases enzymatically degrade the beta-lactam ring of penicillin, rendering it inactive. This is the primary mechanism by which beta-lactamases confer resistance to penicillin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alteration of penicillin binding protein is a resistance mechanism seen in bacteria like MRSA (Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus) but is not the mechanism by which beta-lactamases confer resistance to penicillins.

 

Option C. Drug efflux is a different mechanism of antibiotic resistance where the bacteria pump out the antibiotics like tetracyclines, but it is not the mechanism for beta-lactamase resistance.

 

Option D. Alteration in the 50s ribosome structure is a mechanism of resistance against antibiotics that target the bacterial ribosome, such as macrolides, and is not relevant to beta-lactamase-mediated resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-lactamases confer resistance to penicillins by enzymatically degrading the beta-lactam ring of the antibiotic, rendering it inactive. This is the primary mechanism by which beta-lactamase-producing bacteria evade the effects of beta-lactam antibiotics.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman considers chopping her fingers; she plots and imagines doing so but never accomplishes it. She claims she feels no shame for having such thoughts. Furthermore, she claims that the ideas are disturbing her and that she is unable to control them. The thoughts can stop with a seizure or gradually fade away on their own. Which of the following is the root of the problem? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Forced thinking

 

The patient is experiencing intrusive thoughts that she recognizes as her own but finds distressing and cannot control. The key detail here that differentiates from classic OCD is that these thoughts can stop with a seizure. This phenomenon is called ‘forced thinking’ which is a form of psychic aura.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thought insertion: Thought insertion refers to the belief that one's thoughts are being placed into their mind by an external force.

 

Option C. Crowding of thoughts: Crowding of thoughts refers to the rapid succession of multiple thoughts, typically seen in conditions like mania.

 

Option D. Obsession: Obsession in the context of OCD does involve intrusive, distressing thoughts, but these wouldn't typically cease with a seizure.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Forced thinking is a type of psychic aura which is characterized by recurrent intrusive thoughts, or ideas, which subside on seizure activity.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 510.

choices.text: It is the body's response to anything that requires attention or action causing physical, emotional, or psychological strain

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate definition of stress? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is the body's response to anything that requires attention or action causing physical, emotional, or psychological strain.

 

Stress is a broad term that encompasses the body's physical, emotional, and psychological responses to any demand or threat, whether real or perceived.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. External stress: It is inaccurate as not all stress arises from external pressure. Personal thoughts, emotions, and internal conflicts can also induce stress.

 

Option B. Muscle tension: It simplifies stress to just "mental tension." While mental tension can be a component of stress, the definition doesn't capture the breadth of physiological and psychological reactions associated with stress.

 

Option D. Internal strain: It refers to the outcome of the stress rather than the cause or process of stress itself.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Stress can be conceptualized as the body's adaptive response to demands or threats. It's not just a psychological phenomenon; it has physiological correlates as well. Stressors can be external (e.g., environmental pressures) or internal (e.g., illness, or undergoing a medical procedure), and they can be short-lived (acute) or long-term (chronic).

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 2117

questions.text: A 30-year-old man was admitted to the hospital after three days of abdominal pain and vomiting. His laboratory reports revealed a potassium value of 3.2 mEq/L. All of the following can be seen except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cerebral edema

 

The patient has hypokalemia, indicated by a potassium level of 3.2 mEq/L.

 

This is not seen with Cerebral edema, which is typically associated with hyponatremia (low sodium levels) rather than hypokalemia. Hyponatremia can lead to an osmotic imbalance, causing water to move into brain cells and resulting in cerebral edema. This is not a recognized complication of hypokalemia.

 

Other options:

 

Hypokalemia can lead to several clinical manifestations:

 

Option A. Ventricular tachycardia: Hypokalemia can cause ventricular arrhythmias, including ventricular tachycardia, due to its effect on cardiac electrical activity. Potassium is crucial for maintaining normal heart rhythm, and its deficiency can lead to dangerous arrhythmias.

 

Option B. Quadriparesis: Hypokalemia can cause muscle weakness and paralysis, including quadriparesis. It affects muscle function because potassium is essential for normal muscle cell function and nerve transmission. Severe hypokalemia can mimic conditions like Guillain-Barré syndrome.

 

Option C. Diabetes insipidus: Hypokalemia can cause nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. This condition occurs due to a defect in the kidney's ability to respond to antidiuretic hormone (ADH), leading to excessive urination and thirst. Hypokalemia impairs the kidney's concentrating ability, contributing to this disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebral edema is not associated with hypokalemia; it is a complication of hyponatremia. Hypokalemia can cause ventricular arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

choices.text: 200 mg

questions.text: The maximum dose of PGF2 alpha in postpartum hemorrhage is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 mg

 

Explanation:

 

Prostaglandin F2 alpha (PGF2α), also known as carboprost, is used for the treatment of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) due to uterine atony. The therapeutic regimen and maximum dosage are crucial for effective management and patient safety.

 

  • Dose and Administration: The approved dose for treating uterine atony with PGF2α is 0.25 mg administered intramuscularly (IM).
  • Maximum Dose: The maximum cumulative dose is 2 mg. This is achieved by administering a total of 8 doses of 0.25 mg each.
  • Dosing Interval: These doses can be repeated at intervals of 15 to 90 minutes, depending on the clinical response and the patient's condition.

 

Contraindications

 

  • Bronchial Asthma: PGF2α can cause bronchoconstriction, which makes it contraindicated in patients with bronchial asthma.
  • Suspected Amniotic Fluid Embolism: Due to its potential to cause pulmonary airway and vascular constriction, it is also contraindicated in cases of suspected amniotic fluid embolism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0.25 mg: This is the single dose administered IM but not the cumulative maximum dose.

 

Option C. 20 mg: This dose is excessively high and not clinically recommended or safe.

 

Option D. 200 mg: This dose is not applicable for human use and is far beyond the safe and recommended limits.

 

Educational Objective

 

The maximum dose of prostaglandin F2 alpha in the management of postpartum hemorrhage is 2 mg, administered in 0.25 mg increments intramuscularly.

 

Ref: Page no 480, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

choices.text: Gradual onset of symptoms and normal sleep-wake cycle
Acute onset of symptoms and fluctuating levels of consciousness
Persistent memory loss and normal orientation in early stages
Stable alertness and absence of visual hallucinations

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman with a known history of Alzheimer’s disease is brought to the emergency department by her family because of sudden confusion, agitation, and difficulty recognizing her surroundings over the past two days. Her family reports that she was previously stable with mild memory deficits but has become increasingly disoriented and restless. On examination, she is found to be drowsy with fluctuating levels of alertness, disorganized thinking, and visual hallucinations. Her vital signs are stable, and there is no evidence of focal neurological deficits. Which features best differentiate delirium from her baseline dementia due to Alzheimer's disease? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Acute onset of symptoms and fluctuating levels of consciousness

 

Explanation:

 

Delirium is distinguished from dementia, such as Alzheimer’s disease, by its acute onset and fluctuating levels of consciousness, often accompanied by disturbances in attention and perception. Delirium typically presents abruptly and is marked by a rapid change in mental status, disorganized thinking, and perceptual disturbances like hallucinations. Consciousness is often clouded, and there may be marked diurnal variations with worsening symptoms at night (sundowning). In contrast, Alzheimer’s disease is a chronic, progressive condition with insidious onset, primarily affecting memory and cognitive function, without acute changes in alertness or consciousness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gradual onset of symptoms and normal sleep-wake cycle: These features are more characteristic of dementia, particularly Alzheimer’s disease, where cognitive decline occurs slowly over months to years, and the sleep-wake cycle remains relatively normal until late stages. This presentation does not match the acute and fluctuating course seen in delirium.

 

Option C. Persistent memory loss and normal orientation in early stages: While memory loss is a hallmark of dementia, especially Alzheimer’s disease, early stages often present with relatively preserved orientation and comprehension. In contrast, delirium involves abrupt disorientation and cognitive disturbances that vary throughout the day.

 

Option D. Stable alertness and absence of visual hallucinations: Delirium is frequently associated with visual hallucinations and fluctuating alertness, while dementia patients usually maintain stable alertness without significant hallucinations, particularly in the early and middle stages of the disease. This further highlights the differences between the two conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delirium is characterized by an acute onset, fluctuating levels of consciousness, and disturbed attention, often with visual hallucinations, contrasting with the gradual and insidious progression of dementia, such as Alzheimer’s disease, where consciousness remains intact, and memory impairment is more prominent. Recognizing these differences is critical for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management in clinical practice.
